title: How to Knit on the Right or Wrong Side

steps.headline: Check for differences between the sides.
steps.description: Knitting patterns will result in work that looks different on the right side and the wrong side. By inspecting the work, you can identify which is the right side and which side is the wrong side. For example, when working stockinette stitch (alternating between knitting and purling), then right side is the knit stitches and the wrong side is the purl stitches. Knit stitches lay flat and look similar to braids. Purl stitches are bumpy and look wavy or curvy. Some stitches will produce the same results on both sides of the work, so it is harder to identify the right side and wrong side. For example, garter stitch (knit all stitches on both sides) looks the same on both sides.

steps.headline: Identify the wrong side in color work.
steps.description: Color work is when multiple strands of yarn are used throughout the project. When frequently switching back and forth to create a colorful pattern on one side of a project, the other side will look very different. The right side in color work is the side with stitching and a colorful pattern on it, and the wrong side has the loose strands of yarn.

steps.headline: Look for the wrong side when changing colors.
steps.description: Even when working in a stitch that produces the same results on both sides, such as garter stitch, changing colors can help differentiate the right side from the wrong side. After switching colors, continue working the stitches for a row or two, and compare the sides. The wrong side will have a gap in the colors, rather than two solid colors side by side.

steps.headline: Look for instructions to knit or purl.
steps.description: In some patterns, the right side from wrong side is as simple as knowing when you are knitting and when you are purling. This information will be included in the knitting pattern. Stockinette stitch (St st) is a basic knitting pattern where you alternate between knitting and purling. In this pattern, the knit side is the right side and the purl side is the wrong side. However, in reverse St st, it is the opposite and the purl side is the right side.

steps.headline: Follow the instructions for rs and ws in the pattern.
steps.description: Many knitting patterns provide instructions for how to work the right side (rs) and wrong side (ws). By following instructions, you will know when the row worked is the right side or the wrong side.

steps.headline: See if even and odd rows are labeled.
steps.description: The first row of a knitting pattern can be considered the right side, and the second row can be considered the wrong side. Make sure to keep track of the rows so you know when an odd or even row is being worked.
